title: 103_s1417
content: The Act titled "Wastewater Treatment Operator Training and Certification Act of 1993" amends Section 109 of the Federal Water Pollution Control Act to address operator training. The Administrator is required to develop a national program for training individuals in operating wastewater treatment facilities. This program includes preparing students for careers in wastewater treatment, providing inservice training for current employees in related fields. The Administrator is mandated to establish a training program for operating wastewater treatment facilities, including preservice training for high school graduates not currently employed in this field. Grants will be provided to institutions of higher education and state agencies to develop and implement wastewater treatment training programs. Guidance outlining the minimum program elements will be published within a year. The Administrator will solicit proposals from institutions of higher education and State agencies to provide wastewater training services. Training grants will be awarded to these institutions to develop and implement training programs. The Administrator will consider various factors when awarding training grants to institutions for wastewater training services, including the applicant's capability, program consistency with guidance, evaluation results, and the geographic area to be served. The Administrator will allocate grant funds for training programs based on the need in the area served, as outlined in the report to Congress. Each program funded will be reviewed and evaluated every 3 years. The Administrator will also forecast the supply and demand for various occupational categories. The Administrator will allocate grant funds for training programs based on the need in the area served, as outlined in the report to Congress. Each program funded will be reviewed and evaluated every 3 years. The Administrator will also forecast the supply and demand for various occupational categories needed for the prevention, reduction, and elimination of water pollution in each region, State, or area of the United States. SEC. 3. OPERATOR CERTIFICATION. Amends Section 110 of the Federal Water Pollution Control Act to focus on operator certification. The Chief Operator of a publicly owned treatment works with a permit must be certified as proficient by a State-approved program. The requirement becomes effective 4 years after enactment, with a possible 3-year extension by the Administrator. The Administrator may grant a 3-year extension for certification if adequate opportunity was not available. Certifications are granted to individuals, not treatment works, and are valid for 5 years, with the possibility of renewal every 5 years. Certifications are granted to individuals, not treatment works, and are valid for 5 years, with the possibility of renewal every 5 years. Guidelines specifying minimum standards for certification of operators by a State will be published within 1 year of enactment. The Administrator will establish standards for proficiency certification of treatment works operators, including additional standards for complex systems. A treatment works operator's manual will be published within 1 year of enactment. The Administrator will publish a treatment works operator's manual outlining essential knowledge and skills for Chief Operators and other personnel for operator proficiency certification. State Governors can submit certification programs to the Administrator for approval within 90 days of submission. The Administrator will approve State certification programs that are consistent with guidelines, committed to implementation within 1 year, and agree to provide requested information. The Administrator may consider the effectiveness of a State certification program implemented before the application date when deciding whether to approve it. If the program is disapproved, the Administrator must provide written reasons, and the State can submit modifications within 90 days. The Administrator must approve or disapprove a revised application within 30 days. States can add certification requirements. Enforcement under Section 309(g)(1)(A) of the Act is amended to include additional violations. SEC. 4 amends the Federal Water Pollution Control Act regarding scholarships and representation of minorities and women. SEC. 5 addresses definitions and authorizations. Section 112 of the Federal Water Pollution Control Act is amended to include community colleges, technical colleges, and State environmental agencies. The Administrator is required to submit a report to Congress every 2 years on training, certification, and scholarship programs for water pollution control professionals. Additionally, $15,000,000 is authorized for the Environmental Protection Agency for fiscal years 1994 through 2000 to carry out sections 109 and 111.
